back: the basic unit of sound
a vowel sound that is the combination of two separate sounds where a speaker glides from one to another

the act of the vocal cords either vibrating voiced or not vibrating unvoiced in the
production of a consonant sound
the position in the mouth where a consonant sound is produced
the extent to which airflow is interrupted by parts of the mouth in the production of consonant sounds
a sound unit with a vowel at its centre

a regional variety of speech that differs from other regional varieties in terms of
pronunciation
the ways that individuals adjust their speech patterns to match others
the use of the sound system to mirror form or meaning
an internationally recognised system of phonetic transcription
the literal meanings of words
the  associated meanings of words
language used in a non-literal way in order to describe something in another’s terms eg simile or metaphor
groups of words connected by a shared field of reference eg medicine art
words that have equivalent meanings
words that have contrasting meanings

words that label categories eg animal this category includes for example dog cat
and rabbit
words that can be included in a larger more general category eg the hyponyms car bus aeroplane as a form of the hypernym transport
vocabulary styles including slang colloquialisms taboo formal and fixed levels
a technical vocabulary associated with a particular occupation or activity
a language style associated with a particular social group
a language style associated with a particular geographical region
the process of new word formation including the following blends compounds acronyms initialisms eponyms
the process of words changing meaning including the following narrowing broadening amelioration pejoration semantic reclamation
What the text is about
Things outside the text which may shape its meaning eg when it was written and who wrote it
The opinions expressed in the text
The reason the text has been produced eg to entertain inform persuade etc
The style or voice the text is written in eg excites emotional
The recurring ideas and images in a text
The structure and shape of the text
The type of poem eg sonnet lyric ballad ode narrative poem etc
The division of lines in a poem also called a verse
A poem with a circular structure which begins and ends similarly
A poem of 14 lines divided into an octet and a sestet written in iambic pentameter rhyming abbaabbba cdecde sestet may vary
A poem of 14 lines divided into three quatrains and a couplet written in iambic pentameter rhyming abab cdcd efef gg
The turning point in a sonnet
A two line verse often rhyming
A four-line verse
A six-line verse
An eight line verse
The beats or rhythm in a line of verse
Lines of poetry where the rhyme is on every other line abab
Where the rhyming sound occurs within a line of verse
Where the rhyme looks like it should rhyme but the sound is not exactly the same
Run-on lines
A mid-line pause
The exaggerated phoneme in any particular word
A unit of poetic meter containing one unstressed syllable followed by one stressed syllable -/
A unit of poetic meter containing one stressed syllable followed by one unstressed syllable /-
A unit of poetic meter containing two stressed syllables //
A unit of poetic meter containing one stressed syllable followed by two unstressed syllable /--
A unit of poetic meter containing two unstressed syllables followed by a stressed syllable --/
A unit of poetic meter containing three feet 6 syllables in total
A unit of poetic meter containing four feet 68syllables in total
A unit of poetic meter containing five feet 10 syllables in total
The point of view of the text ie first second or third person
The study of the relationship between words in a sentences
The mood of the sentence often clarified by punctuation
A mood that expresses a command
A mood that expresses strong emotions
A mood used to express a statement
A mood expressing a question
A group of words that has no finite verb except for a verb phrase eg noun phrase ‘the green tree’
A group of words usually with a finite verb which is structurally larger than a phrase
The group of words which carries the core meaning of the sentence
A group of words which add extra information to the independent main clause
A independent main clause
A sentence made up of at least two main clauses joined together by a co-ordinating conjunction
A sentence made up of one main and one or more subordinate or dependent clauses
The patterning of pairs of sounds words or structures to create a sense of balance
A change in the structure of the sentence to place emphasis on an opening sentence element
A change in the structure of the sentence to place emphasis on a closing sentence element
Using conjunctions to join clauses
The omission of co-ordinating conjunctions as a feature of rhetorical style
To place two or more things side by side
The use of apparently contradictory words in a phrase
Listing of three items
Saying the same thing more than once
A grammatical structure in which the subject is the actor of the sentence eg the dog eats the bone
A grammatical structure in which the subject and object can change places in order to alter the focus of a sentence eg the bone was eaten by the dog
The omission of part of a sentence
The deliberate alteration of the structure of words in a sentence
The term used to describe the vocabulary of a language
A naming word
A name for every day objects
A name of a distinctive person place or other unique reference
A name that refers to a group of people animals or things
A name to describe things that have no physical qualities
Words that express states actions or processes
A verb that expresses an action rather than a state
Verbs that express states of being or processes
A verb that precedes another verb eg I can go
A word that modifies a noun or pronoun
A word that modifies verbs adverbs adjectives conjunctions and prepositions
A word that replaces a noun
A word that joins elements of equal rank and or but
A conjunction used to introduce a subordinate clause because while until
A word that shows relationships between nouns or pronouns eg on
The
A
A group of words joined by similarities
The associations attached to a word in addition to its dictionary definition
The words used to name or refer to people when talking to them
Exaggeration used to heighten feeling and intensity
A deliberate understatement
Any variety that does not conform to the standard form as used by society
A word or phrase no longer in current use
A study of spelling and the ways letters are used in language
A structure in which more than one negative is used
A word that emphasizes the extremes eg best worst
An adjective made up of two words joined by a hyphen
A descriptive or metaphorical use of language to create a vivid picture
A device which directly compares two things using like or as eg the tress swayed in the wind like dancers
A description which does not compare one thing with another but actually becomes the other eg the trees danced in the wind
A device in which the non-human is given personal and human qualities eg the trees danced in the wind
When the environment mirrors emotions
To refer to something indirectly or metaphorically
A device in which a word or phrase represents something else
A word that replaces a term seen by society as taboo or unpleasant
A deliberately elaborate metaphor
The study of sound
A set of distinctive pronunciations that mark regional or social identity
The omission of sounds in connected speech
The repetition of the same sound in the initial position in a sequence of words
Sounds where air escapes through a small passage eg f v
Sounds which release a sudden burst of air eg pbt
Consonant sounds articulated with a hissing sound eg sz
Sounds that denote audible breath eg h
Term used to denote sounds made with both lips eg m b
A term used to describe consonants produced with an open nasal passage eg mn
A repetition of the same or similar vowel sounds
The term used to denote words that imitate sounds
The International Phonetic Alphabet used to classify the sounds of language
The study of spoken language
The use of pitch volume pace and rhythm to draw attention to key elements of spoken language
Non-verbal communication using gestures posture and facial expressions
Terms used to denote words that rely on the context to be understood eg pass me that there
Words used when hesitating in speech um er
A commonly occurring phrase in speech eg you know
Language interaction with two or more participants
The quality or tone of the voice in speech
An English accent which has a high social status and is not connected to a specific region
The correction of a mistake or misunderstanding in conversation
An interrogative structure attached to the end of a sentence which expects a reply eg isn’t it
A written record of spoken language which can use symbols and markings to illustrate the distinctive nature of speech
The organization of speakers’ contributions to a conversation
A stretch of spoken language used in stead of ‘sentence’ when discussing spoken language
women more likely to use prestigious pronunciation then men
female language seen as different to established male norm ; female language less assertive
men interrupt more than women in mixed sex convo but men dont interrupt each other; men assert topic control/conversational power

men dominant in convo because dominant in society; social conditioning makes women polite & respectful towards men; their behaviour is less confident and assertive because they occupy a less powerful place in society; women framed negatively in language

convo between men and women sometimes fails because of how men respond/dont respond; men speak twice as long in mixed convo; challenges Lakoff women use questions as a power tool in order to continue convo
women have been taught proper ways to speak; verbal hygiene
women and men have different speech cultures; report talk vs rapport talk
vague language; allows speakers to sound relaxed and informal
language differs on situation specific authority or power NOT gender; women who use low freq of womens lang traits have higher status; hesitancy is about power
women more polite than men; women are more likely to compliment one another than men

women talk to affirm solidarity and maintain relationships; they focus on feelings personal anecdotes & relationships; agree frequently; men find long pauses or thinking time acceptable; frequently disagree and challenge one another - verbal sparring
all female convo falls into 4 categories housetalk; scandal; bitching; chatting - builds on Tannens ideas
practical ways of improving gender equality - use of pronoun them instead of he or she to replace gender bias; replacing marked terms such as job titles with neutral replacements

political correctness is not enough - the need to change society and what it thinks of minority groups; stop arguing about how chairman is sexist and instead understand the issue is that women are underrepresented in parliament
220 terms to describe promiscuous female whereas only 20 to describe men most of which feminise men; insults for men are less taboo and less sexually insulting
Words that show action or state of being They also indicate time Present Past Future
A question asked merely for rhetorical effect and not requiring an answer
the repetition of consonant sounds at the beginning of words
verbs that give orders
Deliberately strong words used to provoke emotion in the reader
word used to modify or describe a noun or pronoun such as happy sad or pretty
exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally
Placement of two things closely together to emphasize comparisons or contrasts
numerical facts
Referring directly to someone or something
A word that modifies a verb an adjective or another adverb
are used to make a comparison between nouns or pronouns eg greater bigger larger
A type of alliteration in which the s sound is repeated
the use of informal words phrases or even slang in a piece of writing
something that actually exists; reality; truth
the exaggerated or hyperbolical expression praise words like best
Combining two words into one
A figure of speech that combines opposite or contradictory terms in a brief phrase
the repetition of vowel sounds eg the rain in Spain falls mainly in the plains
A word that means the same as another word
the giving of human qualities to an animal object or idea
A comparison without using like or as
A comparison using like or as
a statement that seems contradictory or absurd but is actually valid or true
A play on words
a contrast between what is expected and what actually exists or happens
Repeated use of sounds words or ideas for effect and emphasis
A word that imitates the sound it represents
An indirect less offensive way of saying something that is considered unpleasant
A similarity or comparison between two different things or the relationship between them
a short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person
